Description: The Justice Department and Carnival Corp. settlement agreement under the Americans with Disabilities Act to advance equal access for individuals with disabilities who travel on cruise ships.

Princess Cruise Lines Ltd. agreed to pay a $40 million penalty and plead guilty to seven felony charges stemming from the deliberate dumping of oil-contaminated waste from the Caribbean Princess cruise ship.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department
Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Address: BERTH 93A PML/104, WORLD CRUISE LINE CENTER
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: Carnival Corporation pled guilty to federal criminal charges pertaining to the falsification of records related to oil-contaminated discharges at sea.

Private Litigation Case Title: Borcea, et al v. Carnival Corporation

Description: Princess Cruise Lines Ltd. and its parent Carnival Cruise Lines were ordered to pay a $20 million criminal penalty and will be subject to enhanced supervision after admitting to violations of probation attributable to senior Carnival management in a case in which Princess had already paid $40 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Carnival Cruise was fined $27,500 for violating a state environmental law requiring that ships keep emissions from reducing visibility through their exhaust plume by more than 20% while in Alaska waters.

Holland America was fined $192,500 for violating a state environmental law requiring that ships keep emissions from reducing visibility through their exhaust plume by more than 20% while in Alaska waters; $82,500 was suspended.

Info Source: Sewage to cost ship line, Anchorage Daily News, December 8, 2004 (via Nexis).

Description: Robocall violations. The total settlement agreed to by Carnival Corp, Norwegian Cruise Line and Royal Caribbean Cruises was $12.5 million. The settlement did not specify how much each would pay. Here we assume each paid one-third.
Private Litigation Case Title: Charvat v. Travel Services et al

Info Source: Alaska cruise lines pay more than $600,000 in fines for excess smoke, Toronto Star, November 24, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: Settlement of fine under rule 2202 - On-Road Motor Vehicle Mitigation Options
Agency: South Coast (CA) Air Quality Management District

Description: Princess Cruise Lines Ltd. pleaded guilty to a second violation of probation imposed as a result of its 2017 criminal conviction for environmental crimes because it failed to establish and maintain an independent internal investigative office. Under the terms of a plea agreement, Princess was ordered to pay an additional $1 million criminal fine and required to undertake remedial measures to ensure that it and its parent Carnival Cruise Lines establish and maintain the independent internal investigative office known as the Incident Analysis Group (IAG).
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department
